author: phabc
content: <@!543900561460822016> They don't, it's up to the relayer to make sure that when they relay transactions they don't over pay. They can also charge a small premium on all txs to cover their losses for wrong prediction, stop servicing users that to bad relays, blacklist of some type of transactions, etc. Lots of options relayers can explore.

author: phabc
content:
There are basically two camps when it comes to meta-tx risk:

A) If the tx fails or goes off-course, the relayer still gets paid. -> User is "losing" and users have to ensure their txs will go through or the relayer can't make their tx fail
B) If the tx fails or goes off-course, the relayer *does not* get paid. -> Relayer is losing and user has to resubmit, but user doesn't pay. Relayer is the one that has to make sure the txs won't fail or cost too much

I am in camp B) because I believe relayers should be the ones doing all the checks to make sure the tx will go through and the prices are correct, not the user.With B), relayers are incentivized to be "perfect" at predicting. With A) relayers aren't incentivized to do that and could be incentivized to make txs fail. In general, I believe B will provide better services for users and users will tend to go for solutions that are like B and not A. 

Time will tell ðŸ™‚

author: phabc
content: I don't think that's possible, because that would involve no failing transactions or that no-one would have to pay when a transaction fails. If a transaction fails, someone has to pay for the gas: user or relayer

author: phabc
content: I would argue that B is the closest to C, since relayers eventually get really good at knowning when/if txs will fail or not, before paying. Always some unavoidable griefing vectors, but in practice I doubt they will be frequent.
